newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Ecuador's Bucaram begins tour to get presidency back.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador's Bucaram begins tour to get presidency back.

text.p: Ecuador's ousted former president Abdala Bucaram arrived in Argentina on Thursday and vowed to regain his country's presidency.

"I believe that I will be holding the presidency once again this month or next month," Bucaram told reporters at a news conference at his Buenos Aires hotel after lunch with Argentine President Carlos Menem.
"But you have to give me time. I'm not Superman and I can't just get things from one day to the next," he said. "I'm working on it."
Flanked by his son and his former Housing Minister Victor Sicouret, Bucaram declared he would tour Latin America and lobby the Organisation of American States.
Bucaram also said he intended to visit Colombian President Ernesto Samper, Peru's President Alberto Fujimori and Brazil's President Fernando Henrique Cardoso to seek support.
He said that at lunch, Menem had promised to "make the voice of protest heard" over his plight.
Bucaram said that Menem told him he feared that recent events in Ecuador would serve as "a Pandora's Box" threatening the democratic stability of other Latin American countries.

Bucaram was dismissed as president last week by Congress on grounds of "mental incompetency" after a storm of protest over tough austerity measures. His opponents were also irritated by his eccentric style.
Bucaram blasted former Congress speaker Fabian Alarcon, who took over as president on Tuesday. "He is a traitor who betrayed the government and is playing at a coup d'etat."
He said that Ecuador's rich and powerful financial interests had pushed for his ousting.
Bucaram said that despite the lunch with Menem, his visit to Argentina was personal and he had not been invited by the government. He was scheduled to stay until Monday.
